ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This class helped me develop as a person through the analysis of highly relevant literature.
This course improved my close analysis and understanding of Toni Morrison/her importance in African American literature.

How to think critically about Toni Morrison's works of fiction and nonfiction; deeply consider Morrison's demands on readers and learn from her moral imagination among my classmates; try to exercise her lessons in my own life and put her "equipment for living" into practice; do a close reading of Morrison texts in conversation with an annotated bibliography; imagine what I would want to talk with Morrison if I had the chance to talk to her; revisit and revise my midterm paper for my final assignment.

Throughout the course, we read one or more Toni Morrison books each week. We learned how to immerse ourselves in Mrs. Morrison's world by listening to discussions recorded by our professors/TAs as well as engagement with Morrison's interviews, autobiographies and podcasts. I learned how to balance a heavy workload of reading and keeping in mind what Morrison would do personally.
engaging morrison

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: This course moves quickly but is a wonderful environment and community.

Putting together the digital timeline each week and listening to the podcast conversations with Professor Brooks and our TFs really helped me to put my thoughts together in advance of class. I also think that the student presentations were very helpful in putting each work into historical context and learning about what the critical reception of each work was when it came out. I really appreciated the level of communication between Professor Brooks and our TFs with the class in general throughout the course of the semester  it always felt like we were taking care of each other throughout a semester marked by very difficult challenges in the world around us.
At times the course could feel like a lot, but it was understandable because we were trying to get through a lot of Toni Morrison works at once.
Strength is the diversity of morrison material, weakness is the reading load, perhaps reduce the number of books and spread it out over two weeks

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The weekly podcast conversation between Professor Brooks and our TFs I think really helped to fill the space between each seminar, which was more pronounced given the circumstances of the COVID-19 pandemic. Our conversations always felt emotionally sensitive and attuned and it felt like a very safe space for discussion about the works we were reading as well as our lives.

The discussion was very engaging. It was also very structured so we got to maximize time in class. I think I would have appreciate some more breakout rooms but overall amazing class and adapted very well!
success was the daily questions, improvement is more zoom breaks!

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Yes

This was truly the best class I've taken at Yale. I felt that I was challenged to think critically and creatively in a way that I hadn't in any other literature seminar before. The reading load for each week at times felt heavy but I always found myself excited to finish it each week in order to participate as actively as possible in seminar, and learn from my classmates. And of course, I always loved talking about music and Professor Brooks' research interests in conversation with the Morrison texts. Absolutely take this course if you get the chance!
I would recommend this course to another student because immersing yourself in Toni Morrison's world has been amazing! Professor Brooks is also ana amazing and caring professor.
Sure
